Most of those traveling to Martinique will enter through
, located in the suburb of Le Lamentin. Cruise ships often stop in Fort-de-France's harbor.
Mopeds, cars, and taxis are the main mode of transportation.

value: , a fortress on a peninsula in Fort-de-France harbour constructed during the reign of Louis XIII. It currently houses a French naval base, and parts of the fortress have been turned into a museum and are open to the public.
, One the nicest colonial buildings in town is a library, located next to place de la savane.
content=First built in 1671, it was damaged by numerous fires and earthquakes before being totally reconstructed in 1890 by the same architect as the Bibliothèque Schoelcher.
content=A small museum about rum making in the former distillery Dillon. All the rum making process has now moved to a new site.
, a replica of the Montmartre Church in
, constructed in 1925 on a cliff surrounded by tropical forest. Open everyday from 8 to noon and 3 to 6.
directions=10 km away on the road to Morne Rouge
content=Botanical garden with more than 200 species of plants and flowers.
address=Up on the route de Balata, take a left right after the Balata Gardens
content=Easily accessible waterfall where you can swim in the water basin. Park the car just after the bridge and watch out on the slippery steps.
directions=Take the route de Didier from the rond point du Vietnam heroique. Go all the way up, through the tunnel and now you are in the tropical jungle only 10 min from downtown.

content=Trail is not marked, park next to the power generator almost at the end of the road. Walk down towards the river, cross the bridge and up on the other side you ll find a tunnel, bring a flash light. The 1st waterfall is now a 15 min walk away up the river, it is around 6 meter high and jumping from the top is possible. The 2nd waterfall is another 45 mins up the river and consist of a 25 m drop in a basin where you can swim. Watch out for the green and purple matoutou spider on the way.
, in Lamentin (near airport), is the island's largest mall, with several European branded stores and others.
offers stalls full of local/unique flowers, fresh fruit and vegetables, and herbs and spices.
is Fort-de-France's main shopping street... a Paris-like strip of boutiques, island shops and vendors of fresh fruit and flowers
content=If you re travelling by boat, this is the closest to restock on groceries.
hours=Lunch and dinner Monday to Friday, dinner only on Saturdays

Take the ferry to Trois Islets and enjoy crossing the bay by boat.
